Award.AwardTitle: CiC (RDDC): Wordsmith in the Cloud - Refining Language Models Using Web-Scale Language Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
It has never been easier for Web users to express themselves in online communities. The overload of text information generated from online conversations is of concern to various consumer groups. Many effective tools to manage this information overload, such as text retrieval systems, rely on the use of statistical language models. The quality of language models is however limited by the sparseness of data, the mismatch of context, and the incapability of modeling semantic relations.
In this project, cloud computing systems like Azure and Hadoop and novel distributed algorithms will be employed to extract heterogeneous language networks from Web-scale text collections. These language networks will be used to smooth and contextualize language models in various domains, making them accurate and robust. The refined language models will help improve state-of-the-art text retrieval and mining techniques, enhancing the information access and knowledge acquisition experience of real users across community and language boundaries.
The techniques and resources (e.g., language networks and refined language models) will benefit a broad range of users that analyze text content in social media and many other domains. Research results of this project, including software tools and resources, will be published on the project Web site (http://www-personal.umich.edu/~qmei/wordsmith/).

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. We developed a technique for constructing networks of language -- words and phrases linked based on how frequently they appear in the same context, from very large collections of text documents. The technique is built upon cloud-based computational systems and algorithms, which is able to process document collections with the size similar to the entire Wikipedia in minutes. These language networks can be used to improve the performance of search engines, document classification systems, and many other natural language processing applications.

2. We developed a technique for computing a mathematical representation of the meanings of words and phrases based on language networks. Using this representation, a software tool can easily compute how similar the meanings of two words are. The technique can also be used to compute how related two users are in a social network. It can be applied to improving document classification, content and friend recommendation in social networks, and visualizing large networks.  

3. By constructing a network of scientific innovations (e.g., new techniques) from scientific publications, we were able to study how interrelated innovations influence a scientist's decision of using one or the other. We found that a scientist is more likely to use a new technique if he has used similar or competing techniques before.

4. We developed a technique for building a consumer health vocabulary -- health and healthcare related words and phrases that are frequently used by the common Internet users, and matching them to the corresponding professional medical terms. We identified thousands of pairs of consumer terms and professional terms at a high accuracy, based on co-reference and redirecting patterns in Wikipedia. This consumer health vocabulary is useful for providing a better service to the consumers of health information through search engines, recommender systems, and reading assisting tools.
